evidence.source_document: Final Order Approving Compromise and Settlement Agreement
evidence.text: Pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(e), the Settlement Agreement is fair, adequate, and reasonable.

extracted.value: The court approved the Settlement Agreement as fair, adequate, and reasonable under Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(e).

evidence.source_document: Final Order Approving Compromise and Settlement Agreement
evidence.text: This action is hereby dismissed with prejudice, subject to the retention of jurisdiction as hereafter provided.

extracted.value: The court dismissed the action with prejudice, subject to retention of jurisdiction.

evidence.source_document: Final Order Approving Compromise and Settlement Agreement
evidence.text: Each Settlement Class Member is hereby barred and permanently enjoined from prosecuting, commencing or continuing any of the Released Claims against the Released Parties.

extracted.value: The court barred Settlement Class Members from prosecuting Released Claims against Released Parties.

evidence.text: The Magistrate Judge ruled that whether defendants have publicly stated that children in DHS custody are safer because of the reduction in the number of children in state custody does not expand the claims or defenses in the case, and therefore the discovery sought by plaintiffs was not relevant. He granted the defendants’ motion to quash.

extracted.value: The court granted defendants' motion to quash depositions, ruling the requested discovery regarding DHS's policy on assessments versus investigations was not relevant to the claims or defenses.

evidence.text: The court rejects defendants’ Younger challenge. In summary, the court concludes that most of the general forms of relief requested by plaintiffs do not pose a risk of interference with state court juvenile proceedings.

extracted.value: The court denied defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction under the Younger abstention doctrine, concluding that most forms of relief sought by plaintiffs do not pose a risk of interfering with ongoing state juvenile proceedings.

evidence.text: Defendant Howard Hendricks’ Motion to Compel [Dkt. 172] is DENIED.

extracted.value: The court denied Defendant Howard Hendricks' Motion to Compel, ruling the motion was not appropriate under Fed.R.Civ.P. 34 as both parties had equal access to documents.

evidence.text: Plaintiffs’ Motion to Compel the Production of E–Mails [Dkt. 181] as modified at the hearing on February 19, 2009, is GRANTED.

extracted.value: The court granted Plaintiffs' Motion to Compel the Production of E–Mails, requiring Plaintiffs to provide a preliminary expert report identifying relevant documents by May 22, 2009.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Children’s Motion for Leave to File Two Rebuttal Expert Reports, [Dkt. 539], is DENIED.

extracted.value: The court denied Plaintiff Children's Motion for Leave to File Two Rebuttal Expert Reports, ruling that the proposed testimony did not constitute 'rebuttal evidence' as defined by Fed.R.Civ.P. 26(a)(2)(D)(ii) and would disrupt the court schedule.

evidence.text: the Twenty-Second Commentary of the Co-Neutrals constitutes the Final Report for the seven Delayed Performance Area Measures. The Department’s obligations under the Compromise and Settlement Agreement, as amended, with respect to the seven Delayed Performance Area Measures are terminated.

extracted.value: The court concluded that the Department's obligations under the Compromise and Settlement Agreement, as amended, with respect to the seven Delayed Performance Area Measures are terminated, following the Co-Neutrals' Twenty-Second Commentary finding good faith efforts for a continuous two-year period.

evidence.text: the defendants’ obligations under the Compromise and Settlement Agreement are satisfied.

extracted.value: The court ordered that the defendants' obligations under the Compromise and Settlement Agreement are satisfied, having previously terminated obligations for the twenty-three Non-Impacted Performance Area Measures.
